channel.title: How to change the input to something else
channel.description:
hi all i just want to know im just using java.util.* for this i want to know how i can change what is typed in so i have set values on a pice of paper for each letter so "a = 12" something like that going through the alphabet
so if some on was to type in hello h would have a set value lets say 432 e would also have a set value lets say 885 l would also have a set value lets say 753 l would be the same as the other l so it would be 753 o would also have a set value lets say 848
so the program would output 432885753753848 for hello for spaces it would be just a - so if some one types in hello hello it would out put 432885753753848-432885753753848
can any one help me / write this program just change the values to a=a b=b for now and i can change them
need any more info just let me know

item.title: How to change the input to something else
item.dc:creator: @1337h4x 1337h4x
item.description:
@1337h4x wrote:

try using

int numbershit = (int) "a".toCharArray()[0];

item.title: How to change the input to something else
item.dc:creator: @iwasinmoparseas101cl iwasinmoparseas101class
item.description:
@iwasinmoparseas101cl wrote:

arrays would be good, but that’s a HUGE ASS area of memory taken away (1000 used with only 26 lower, 26 upper, special characters). I’d say go with White Castles idea with a HashMap with possibly <Int, String> as the arguements instead of <String, String>. But if you are more comfortable in dealing with just strings, work with those

Read full topic

item.title: How to change the input to something else
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

i think arrays could be good

{
 String[] list;
 list = new String[1000];

 list[432] = "h";
 list[885] = "e";
 list[753] = "l";
 list[848] = "o";



 System.out.println(list[432]+list[885]+list[753]+list[753]+list[848]);
}

item.title: How to change the input to something else
item.dc:creator: @White_Castle White Castle
item.description:
@White_Castle wrote:

[code]import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.Scanner;

public class Fuckshit {
public static HashMap<String, String> values = new HashMap<String, String>();
public static void main(String[] args) {
values.put(“a”, “1”);
values.put(“b”, “2”);
values.put(“c”, “3”);
values.put(“d”, “4”);
values.put(“e”, “5”);
values.put(“f”, “6”);
values.put(“g”, “7”);
values.put(“h”, “8”);
values.put(“i”, “9”);
values.put(“j”, “10”);
values.put(“k”, “11”);
values.put(“l”, “12”);
values.put(“m”, “13”);
values.put(“n”, “14”);
values.put(“o”, “15”);
values.put(“p”, “16”);
values.put(“q”, “17”);
values.put(“r”, “18”);
values.put(“s”, “19”);
values.put(“t”, “20”);
values.put(“u”, “21”);
values.put(“v”, “22”);
values.put(“w”, “23”);
values.put(“x”, “24”);
values.put(“y”, “25”);
values.put(“z”, “26”);
System.out.print(“Enter: “);
String result = new String();
for(String s : new Scanner(System.in).nextLine().split(” “)) {
for(String t : s.split(””)) {
if(!t.equals("")) {
String value = values.get(t);
if(value == null) {
throw new RuntimeException(“Unmapped value “” + t + “””);
}
result += value;
}
}
result += “-”;
}
result = result.substring(0, result.length() - 1);
System.out.println("Result: " + result);
}
}[/code]

Haven’t compiled it.

Read full topic
